abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Capacity Building
            Project for Economic Management is rated as satisfactory.
            Capacity building and technical assistance are essential to
            the implementation of a reform program in a country such as
            Chad, which has been devastated by years of civil strife. In
            turn, the reform program, by putting emphasis on revenue
            mobilization and improved budgetary procedures, was
            essential to the rebuilding of public administration. The
            project was specifically designed to help Chad implement its
            reform program, supported by three adjustment credits. The
            reform program was implemented successfully, and Chad has
            been able to make critical progress in the management of its
            public resources. This would not have been possible without
            assistance provided under the project. Capacity building is
            a long-term endeavor, which requires sustained government
            commitment. The project developed local capacity, but much
            remains to be done, particularly as Chad is gearing up to
            vastly increased resources from petroleum exploitation in
            coming years. During the review process, Bank management
            insisted that operating expenditures to be financed under
            the credit be kept at a minimum, so as to ensure
            sustainability. The allocation in the credit agreement was
            small and experience has showed that it was far from
            adequate in view of Chad's constrained fiscal
            situation. During project implementation, the allocation was
            increased, which was critical for moving the reform program ahead.
